Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project: Bowie State Plant Science Initiative

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) supported Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Targeted Infusion Project at Bowie State University (BSU) lays the foundation for a concentration in the institution's plant science curriculum. Undergraduate students are introduced to interdisciplinary teaching and cross-disciplinary research to meet 21st century global challenges in sustainable energy, environmental and climate change as well as renewable and green energy research. The goals of the project at this minority-serving institution are to:
1. Increase student interest, understanding, and research competencies in Plant Sciences through academic and summer faculty and peer-mentored research;
2. Infuse an interdisciplinary approach to Plant Science;
3. Create and implement a laboratory intensive Plant Science course;
4. Enhance the General Biology and Plant Physiology laboratory course curricula by integrating research and introducing new experiments into the curriculum; and,
5. Develop state-of-the-art teaching and research infrastructure in Plant Science laboratories through the acquisition of new research equipment.

Collaboration with University of Maryland and other research organizations, acquisition of new research equipment, faculty and student STEM professional development will result in a sustainable plant science program for BSU and the surrounding community. Evaluation and dissemination activities will be shared throughout the institution's STEM community and broader through BSU's website, presentations at STEM research and education conferences and publications in STEM journals.

The project aligns with the College of Arts and Sciences strategy of promoting the engagement of minorities in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines through integrated and diversified experiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

The greatest outcome of The Bowie State Plant Science Initiative (BSPSI) Targeted Infusion project is the advancement of plant science knowledge through research which resulted in twenty research papers and posters. One project investigated potential metabolic stimulators (Salicylic Acid and Benzoic Acid) effect on the production of alpha and beta carotene in carrots. High performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was used to analyze carotene produced by carrot plants treated with elicitors during studies. This study’s outcome is a production of a technology of the production of nutritious super carrots. Carotenoids, produced by carrot, of which alpha and beta-carotene are examples of, are known natural killers of cancer cells. The other research focus was on the use of High Performance Thin Layer Chromatography(HPTLC) to analyze the phytochemical profiles in Azadirecta indica, Neem tree and compared this with the profiles in Melia azaderach.

The next outcome is enhanced the research capability of the PI by providing opportunities and resources for research. Due to the acquisition of state-of-the-art new equipment, more students and faculty are now able to perform research. Collaboration and interdisciplinary nature of the project has increased research.

 

Involving minority students in international research experience was transformative outcome. A total of five (5) students went to Kenya, Africa for an international research experience. Our host was Professor Sheila Okoth. Apart from research the students also had a chance to experience Kenya as they visited many sites in the country. Working side by side with international scientist from different cultures, the students learned different cultures.

 

The program was well conceived and organized. Working with the Advisory Committee composed of the external evaluator and the university leadership such as the Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences, the Chair of Natural Sciences Department and the Director of Research and Sponsored Programs helped to shape the program direction right from the onset. The planning of the international component required very well organized and conceived plan.

 

Improvement of the research Infrastructure and resources is a great outcome of this program. This was e done by the purchase of the state of the art equipment including, I) High Performance Liquid Chromatography(HPLC); (Shimadzu LC-20A Series); ii). Growth Chamber; Conviron ATC40; iii) CAMAG High Performance Thin Layer Chromatography (HPTLC); iv) Qubit Systems photosynthesis laboratory package and v). Qubit System (Q-Box NF1LP) Nitrogen Fixation Package and a class II biological safety cabinet.  

Broader impacts:

The program advanced discovery by creating and implementing a research intensive Plant Science course called Introduction to Plant Metabolomics. More than 56 students have participated in this course in the life of this program. Every student was assigned a research project that he/she did throughout the semester. Furthermore, research was infused into the General Botany and Plant Physiology laboratory course curricula and new experiments were introduced into the curriculum. The Focus of the general Botany course was the carrot project is discussed above. The focus of the plant physiology was on real time Photosynthesis experiments using Infra-Red gas analyzers.

 

Increasing student interest, understanding, and research competencies in Plant Sciences was a great outcome and was done by infusing research into the curriculum. A total of about 672 minority undergraduate Biology majors were involved in this project throughout the life of the project by enrolling in General biology, Plant Physiology and Introduction to Plant Metabolomics courses. At least four students per year were involved in full time summer research and part time fall and spring research.

 

Developing the state-of -the- art teaching and research infrastructure in Plant Science laboratories is another outcome and was done through acquisition of new instrumentation. Through this program, we were able to buy state of the art equipment including; Through this program, we have a very strong collaboration with United States Department of Agriculture Food Composition methods laboratory where our students have been attached. We were also able to form an international collaboration with University of Nairobi in Kenya.

 

Dissemination of more than 20 student research papers and posters is one of the great outcomes. The students presented their research regionally and nationally at conferences included Annual Plant Biology Conference and Emerging Researchers National Conferences.

 

The focus of the research which was on the enhancement of alpha and beta carotene levels in carrot. This is most likely to improve the health of the population and benefit the society. The carotene is a carotenoid of increasing demand as precursor of vitamin A, which has also been ascribed a central role in cancer prevention and therapy.  The technology to improve carrots and produce a super carrot is another outcome. This is an easy technique which can be shared with the society for production of nutritious carrots. One undergraduate student participants got Ph.D Program admission, and a total of 3 students were admitted to professional schools,  for Doctor of pharmacy program .
